DataElement.preferredName: Thymus Gland Disease Assessment Timepoint Total Volume
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Numeric value for the volume in cubic centimeters (cm3) of the thymus gland at the time of a disease assessment.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Thymus Gland Disease Assessment Timepoint Volume
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A bi-lobed organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is located in the upper anterior portion of the chest, behind the sternum. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and fewer epithelial cells. Connective tissue septa separate the lobes into lobules. The lobules contain an outer portion (cortical zone) which is rich in lymphocytes and an inner portion (medullary zone) which is rich in epithelial cells. It is an organ essential for the development of the immune system. Its function is the maturation of the progenitor lymphoid cells to thymocytes and subsequently to mature T-cells. It reaches its greatest weight at puberty and subsequently begins to involute._The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of._A specific point in the time continuum, including those established relative to an event._The amount of three dimensional space occupied by an object or the capacity of a space or container.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A bi-lobed organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is located in the upper anterior portion of the chest, behind the sternum. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and fewer epithelial cells. Connective tissue septa separate the lobes into lobules. The lobules contain an outer portion (cortical zone) which is rich in lymphocytes and an inner portion (medullary zone) which is rich in epithelial cells. It is an organ essential for the development of the immune system. Its function is the maturation of the progenitor lymphoid cells to thymocytes and subsequently to mature T-cells. It reaches its greatest weight at puberty and subsequently begins to involute.

Concepts.definition: A bi-lobed organ surrounded by a connective tissue capsule. It is located in the upper anterior portion of the chest, behind the sternum. It is composed predominantly of lymphocytes and fewer epithelial cells. Connective tissue septa separate the lobes into lobules. The lobules contain an outer portion (cortical zone) which is rich in lymphocytes and an inner portion (medullary zone) which is rich in epithelial cells. It is an organ essential for the development of the immune system. Its function is the maturation of the progenitor lymphoid cells to thymocytes and subsequently to mature T-cells. It reaches its greatest weight at puberty and subsequently begins to involute.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The number of the whole or complete volume; the amount of 3-dimensional space occupied by an object.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: The values that are permitted for the usual or expected function of something; the part something plays in an action or event. [Source: NCI]

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete.:Volume; the amount of 3-dimensional space occupied by an object.:Number; a concept of quantity derived from zero and units; a numeral or string of numerals that is used for identification.

Concepts.definition: Pertaining to an entirety or whole, also constituting the full quantity or extent; complete; derived by addition.
The amount of three dimensional space occupied by an object or the capacity of a space or container.
A numeral or string of numerals expressing value, quantity, or identification.
